Description: Tiny ToCS is a forum for high-quality scholarly discourse that challenges researchers to engage with their work in new capacities. Not only does the restricted format require a concise distillation of scholarly results, but the short format will be more accessible to the Computer Science community at large. Tiny ToCS favors accessible, carefully crafted, creative research, and invites submissions both about novel ideas as well as summaries or distillations of existing work.

Items.Title: Is Ordering of Disk Updates Required to Maintain File-System Crash-Consistency?
Items.Abstract: Not only is it possible to maintain file-system crash-consistency without ordering updates, but doing so may actually increase performance.

Items.Title: Smart Thread Scheduling is the Key for OLTP
Items.Abstract: Instructions need capacity: Use multiple L1-I. Data misses are compulsory: Share within a socket. Thread scheduling is the key for OLTP.

Items.Title: C/C++ Causal Cycles Confound Compositionality
Items.PersonsString: Mike Dodds, Mark Batty and Alexey Gotsman
Items.AffiliationsString: University of York, University of Cambridge and IMDEA Software Institute
Items.Abstract: C/C++ permit seemingly-impossible cycles in causality. This breaks compositionality: two apparently safe programs may fault when composed.

Items.Title: Clustering reveals ubiquitous heterogeneity and asymmetry of genomic signals at functional elements
Items.PersonsString: Anshul Kundaje, Sofia Kyriazopoulou-Panagiotopoulou, Max W. Libbrecht, Cheryl L. Smith, Debasish Raha, Elliott E. Winters, Steven M. Johnson, Michael Snyder, Serafim Batzoglou and Arend Sidow
Items.Abstract: Aggregation plots cannot represent asymmetrical signals around sets of unoriented sites. Clustering is necessary for such analysis.

Items.Title: First-order theorem proving in the exploration of Andrews-Curtis conjecture
Items.Abstract: Potential counterexamples to Andrews-Courtis conjecture can be refuted efficiently by automated theorem proving.

Items.Title: Towards Provable Remote Data Deletion Through Quantum Entanglement
Items.AffiliationsString: University of Cambridge and Queen Mary University London
Items.Abstract: If we connect two qubits via quantum entanglement, the fate of one can be controlled by the other so shared secrets can be deleted remotely.

Items.Title: Predicting Recommender System Performance from an Information Retrieval Perspective
Items.PersonsString: Alejandrio Bellogín, Pablo Castells and Iván Cantador
Items.Abstract: We develop new recommendation effectiveness prediction methods based on query clarity. Recommendation performance is, in fact, predictable.

Items.Title: Experienced old eyes can look young in HCI research
Items.PersonsString: Robin L. Hill, Anna Dickinson and John L. Arnott
Items.AffiliationsString: University of Edinburgh and University of Dundee
Items.Abstract: When experience is controlled for, older adults' eye movements resemble younger adults. Age alone is less important than previously assumed.

Items.Title: Punctuation has a point, so use it!
Items.PersonsString: Robin L. Hill and Wayne S. Murray
Items.AffiliationsString: University of Edinburgh and University of Dundee
Items.Abstract: Too many TTS and ASR systems ignore punctuation. Mistake! Little things can make a difference for the better.

Items.Title: A Restriction-Centered Theory of Reasoning and Computation to materialize a Web 3.0
Items.Abstract: Mimicking human thinking, the RRC theory allows building reasoners, which can deal with fuzzy reality. Such reasoners may enable a Web 3.0.

Items.Title: HW Databases, Where art Thou?
Items.PersonsString: Sangjin Han, Aurojit Panda and Sylvia Ratnasamy
Items.Abstract: We need an open HW specification database that is comprehensive, extensible, maintainable, and accessible by both humans and machines.

Items.Title: See straight through data center bandwidth limitations with X-Rays
Items.Abstract: Reconfigurable wireless X-Ray links in data centers could deliver 40 Pb/sec, but would have to be turned off while operators are present.

Items.Title: Using MOOCs as a global testbed for network measurement
Items.Abstract: Researchers gain insights on global scale internet by using #MOOC students as vantage points. Students learn from the assignments. Win win.

Items.Title: Detecting DNS Censorship without an internal vantage point
Items.PersonsString: Will Scott, Sujit Packiaraj and Arvind Krishnamurthy
Items.Abstract: DNS censorship can be detected through anomalies when querying public DNS servers. At least 13 countries block otherwise available sites.

Items.Title: Securing Two-factor Authentication for Smartphones in a Usable Way by Adding a Connected Token
Items.Abstract: Two-factor authentication for smartphones is easy to break and can be secured by using a smart watch which acts as a connected token.

Items.Title: Don't show your hand: on the security leakages of *BFT systems
Items.Abstract: The reply messages of the *BFT distributed systems expose the status of your servers and turn you into a target for malicious attackers.

Items.Title: How soon can you decide whether Alice is permitted to communicate or share resources with Bob?
Items.Abstract: Guaranteeing access control policy evaluation performance is hard. Results from scalable web systems and semantic analysis show promise.

Items.Title: Android Apps: What are they doing with your precious Internet?
Items.PersonsString: Amy Tang, Ashwin Rao, Justine Sherry and Dave Choffnes
Items.AffiliationsString: University of California Berkeley, INRIA and University of Washington
Items.Abstract: The majority of Android apps are not malicious, but use internet access in ways that are not compatible with the user's interests.

Items.Title: Recency is good: expanding with fresh news improves event detection in Twitter
Items.PersonsString: Saša Petrović, Miles Osborne and Victor Lavrenko
Items.Abstract: Expanding tweets with fresh and with stale newswire improves event detection by 21% and 17% respectively, compared to not using expansion.

Items.Title: Men at work: the StackOverflow case
Items.PersonsString: Bogdan Vasilescu, Andrea Capiluppi and Alexander Serebrenik
Items.AffiliationsString: Eindhoven University of Technology and Brunel University
Items.Abstract: StackOverflow users presenting themselves as women participate less and earn less reputation than those presenting themselves as men.

Items.Title: Exploiting User Behaviors from Today's Online Social Networks to Build Distributed Alternatives
Items.Abstract: Can we make decentralized online social networks highly available by mining online trends of users on today's OSNs?

Items.Title: The Case of Coopetition: Facebook and Decentralized Alternatives
Items.Abstract: A new way of social networking: decentralized alternatives can plug into Facebook as 3rd party apps to overcome the network effect.

Items.Title: The next step in software metrics research
Items.Abstract: To enable the effective application of software metrics, a pattern catalog based on real-world usage scenarios must be developed.

Items.Title: Adaptation is a Game
Items.PersonsString: Roberto Bruni, Andrea Corradini, Fabio Gadducci, Alberto Lluch Lafuente and Andrea Vandin
Items.AffiliationsString: Universita di Pisa and IMT Institute for Advanced Studies Lucca
Affiliations: IMT Institute for Advanced Studies Lucca
IMT Institute for Advanced Studies Lucca
Items.Abstract: Control data variants of game models such as Interface Automata are suitable for the design and analysis of self-adaptive systems.

Items.Title: Applying existing software metrics to development release cycles
Items.Abstract: We think product metrics can help us understand release cycles. This understanding can in turn improve the software development process.

People.Name: Alberto Lluch Lafuente
People.Affiliation: IMT Institute for Advanced Studies Lucca

People.Name: Andrea Vandin
People.Affiliation: IMT Institute for Advanced Studies Lucca
